OF MINISTERIAL SUB-COMMITTEE OF HOME POLICY JOMMITTESON (A) SUGAR SUPPLIES AND CONSUMPTION (B) THE tQAT POSITION. 1. A Ministerial Sub-Corami ttee of the Home Policy Coiamittee was recently constituted as follows :- Lord Pri\-y Seal (Chairman) Secretary of State for the Colonies Minister of Food Secretary of State for Scotland President of the Board of Trade Minister of Health Minister of Agriculture and Fisheries M i n i s t e r of Shipping Financial Secretary to the Treasury to keep under continuous and close review the "broader aspects of the problems of Food Policy. This Ministerial Sub-Committee are assisted by an Interdepartmental Sub- Committee under the Chairmanship of Sir H. J , Wilson and cornposed of the Permanent Heads of the Departments concerned. 2. We decided to examine in the first instance the most pressing and urgent aspects of the problem, namely :( a) Sugar Supplies and Consumption (b) The Meat Position (c) The Cereals Position (d) The possibilities of increasing Home Production in 1940. i3 * We attach hereto Reports of the Official Sub- Committee (Appendices I and II) on Sugar Supplies and Consumption, and the Meat Position respectively in the form agreed by us for submission to the War Cabinet.
I (j 0 4 . Sugar Supplies and Consumption. It will "be observed that for the reasons set out in the Report of the Official Sub-Gommittee (Appendix I) we recommend that the rationing of sugar should, begin on the 8th. January, 1940 (the date on which Bacon and. Butter are to be rationed) and that the sugar ration should, be 12 ounces per head per week for domestic consumption, and 8 ounces for manufacturing purposes. If this recommendation is accepted it would not be necessary to make any announcement about sugar rationing earlier than December 27th. 5, We have considered a suggestion that in view of the strong expression of opinion of the Exchange Requirements Committee that the rationing of sugar should be instituted with the least possible delay (see paragraph 5 of Appendix I) sugar rationing might start from an earlier date than January Sth. We think, however, that the objections to so doing outand weigh the advantages,/that in particularit would be politicimmediately ally impracticable to introduce the rationing of sugar/before Christmas, especially having regard to the Answers given by the Minister of Rood in the House of Commons on November 28th., in which in reply to Questions by Mr. Alexander and others he made an appeal for a period of trial of voluntary rationing. 6. We are agreed that -it would be wiser to start with a 12 ounce domestic ration and to increase that ration to 16 ounces at a later date if found practicable than to begin on January 8th., with a 16 ounce ration which would almost certainly have to be reduced in a few weeks time. The Minister of Health is anxious that the sugar ration should be bought up to 16 ounces as soon as possible, and for this ^ason is disposed to favour the purchase of 400,000 tons of
foreign sugar as set out in column 4 of the table to Appendix I. The other Members of the Committee favour the restriction of the foreign purchases of sugar to 300,000 tons as set out in column 5 of the table, and in this connection the Secretary of State for the Colonies has drawn the special attention of the Jommittee to the serious reactions on the Empire producers of sugar of purchasing at an enhanced price larger quantities of foreign sugar than are absolutely essential. The Minister of Health has reserved his position on this point. The Meat Position and the Rationing of meat in the New Year. 7. Since the War Cabinet decided in October last not to ration meat, the statistical position as from the end of next January has deteriorated for the reasons explained in paragraph 3 of Appendix II, i. e, (a) shortage of foodstuffs has led to abnormal slaughtering and consequently home supplies will be substantially less next Spring than was anticipated. (b) Increased shipping delays; and (c) The French requirement of 20,000 tons of frozen meat a month has materialised. 8. With regard to (a) it is clear that the shortage of foodstuffs has caused farmers to sell an abnormal amount of livestock. While this has eased the immediate supply position it will clearly result in a corresponding shortage in the amount of livestock coming on to the market in the Spring of 1940. The tables attached to Appendix II take this prospective shortage into account. (b) Shipping delays and difficulties have been Intensified by the new enemy mining campaign, and it must be remembered that shipping equipped with the necessary -3refrigerating space is highly specialised and in the not improbable event of losses being sustained, such shipping oannot easily be replaced. (c) Normally Prance is not a heavy importer of frozen meat, hut when the French Army mobilised such meat was at once required in order inter alia to provide a mobile reserve for the Army. So long as the French troops occupy static positions it is possible to feed them in the traditional French fashion, namely, by livestock driven up and slaughtered behind the line, but circumstances may well render this practice highly undesirable, and indeed impossible, and for this reason a reserve of frozen meat is considered by the French Military Authorities to be an essential requirement. This we think in the circumstances to be a reasonable proposition. In order to suit our convenience the French have refrained from entering the South American meat market as competitors with us for the purchase of meat. They have also been prepared to deal reasonably with us in the matter of wheat supplies. 9, In effect this French request is for the provision of at least 10,000 tons a month of British refrigerated tonnage so as to enable the French to lift their requirements. At the same time it will be appreciated that if this request is granted a reduction of 10,000 tons of imported meat per month for civilian consumption in the United Kingdom is involved. We consider that the shipping position should be further examined in consultation with the French Government with a view to seeing whether it may not be possible to make some reduction in that Government1s requirements so far as British refrigerated tonnage is concerned.
10, ' It should he observed that in October last the meat ration contemplated was one of 27 ounces and that as stated in paragraph 6 of Appendix II the supplies during the months March, April and May, 1940, will only suffice to provide a ration of 20 ounces per head per week as compared with the current consumption of 40 ounces.
Our recommend a t i ons to the War Cabinet may be summarised as follows ; Sugar Supplies and 0onsump11on (l) That Sugar should be rationed as from 8 t h o January, 1 9 4 0 (the date on which Bacon and Butter are being rationed), and that the Sugar ration should be 12 ounces per head per week for domestic consumption, and S ounces per head per week for manufacturing purposes. ( 2 ) That the arrangements should be based on the acceptance of column 5 of the Table to Appendix I, namely, foreign purchases of Sugar of 3 0 0 , 0 0 0 tons, and rations of the amount mentioned in (l) above, -Noteo The Minister of Health has reserved his position in regard to this recommendation, (3) That i t should be noted that the decision in (1) above need not be announced before December 27th, The Meat Position.and Meat Rationing (l) That consumers should register with retailers of meat during the week beginning Isto January, 1 9 4 0. ( 2 ) That the scheme for the control of livestock and home produced meat should be brought into operation on 15tho January, 1 9 4 0 c (3) That the question of the introduction of Meat rationing should be further considered when registration has been effected, and that in the meantime the Ministry of Pood should proceed on the basis that rationing will in'fact he necessary early in 1 9 4 0 . (4) That it will not be necessary to make any announcement in regard to (l) and (3) above until after Christmas; the decision in regard to (2) above has already been announced without mention, however, of any specific date. (5) That the French tonnage requirements for the shipment of frozen Meat should be further examined by the Minister of Shipping in consultation with the Minister of Foodo
12. We hope to be in a position to circulate to the War Cabinet early next week a Report on the Cereal position, and later in the week a Report on the question of increased home production of foodstuffs in 1940. Signed on behalf of the Sub-Committee SAMUEL HOARE. CHAIRMAN. nd Terrace, S. W. 1* 2nd. December, 1939.

In addition tonnage will be required for the 400,000 or 300,000 tons of foreign sugar shewn in Columns 4 & 5 respectively. 5. The statistical table accounts in column 1. for the whole of the Empire sugar which has already been purchased with the exception of 122,000 tons from Queensland. This 122,000 tons is included in the 442,500 tons referred to in paragraph 4 as being the quantity of Empire sugar already purchased for which shipping arrangements have not yet been made. In calculating the deficiency which will have to be made up by the purchase of foreign sugar, it has been assumed that the whole of the Queensland purchase will b e received in the United kingdom later in 1940. 6. The Sterling requirements for foreign currency under Columns 4 and 5 are £1,800,000 and £3,600,000 respectively. The Exchange Requirements Committee, after a careful examination of the whole situation, are constrained to accept the necessity of providing foreign Exchange for the purchase of the additional quantity of foreign sugar required to implement the arrangement set out in Column 5- They are concerned, however, to ensure the avoidance of the further large demands for Exchange for sugar? purohases that will he entailed if that arrangement is not put into operation and they have submitted a strong recommendation in favour of rationing of sugar from the earliest practicable date on the scale shown in Column 5o 7. It is suggested that in order to economise foreign exchange, and shipping tonnage, as well as to avoid the necessity of paying an extravagant price for foreign sugar the War Cabinet should be recommended to authorise the rationing of Sugar on the 8th January, 1940 (the date on which Bacon and Butter are to be rationed) and that the sugar ration should be 12 oz. per head per week for domestic consumption and 8 oz. for manufacturing purposes. R E X (Revise) WAR CABINET. HOME POLICY COMMITTEE. MINISTERIAL COMMITTEE ON THE FOOD POLICY. RATIONING OF MEAT IN THE NEW YEAR. Ilemorandum by the Official Sub-Committee. The decision taken last October by the War Cabinet not o ration meat was taken in the light of the statistical position 3 then known. From estimates of hone supplies and from the stimated arrivals of known shipments of imported meat it was alculated that, after putting aside 30,000 tons of imported meat nthe three months, 1 s t November, 1939* to 31st January, 1940, wards building up a reserve (over and above a normal working stock fapproximately 60,000 tons) sufficient meat would be available for average weekly supply of 26 ozs. " of meat per head of the ivilian population and for the next three months 24 ozs.s The "ses of these figures are indicated in the attached Annex la and b. The normal average weekly consumption pur head of meat (other than aeon and ham) is approximately 2^ lbs, but it is known that large actions of the population eat considerably less than this. The ra&y position for the three months November to January was before considered to be satisfactory, and that rationing could ;0t reasonably have been introduced during this period on the rounds of a serious shortage of supply. H These are revised figures. 29 ozs. and 24 ozs. respectively were given in the Report of the Rationing Sub-Committee, 23rd October, 1939."
s. d £ jne War Cabinet's decision was based on a review of the supply sition made in the middle of October, Since then three important have occurred which necessitate a reconsideration of the Ranges ective supplies of meat. pros? (a) The shortage of feeding-stuffs has developed at a greater rate than had then been anticipated with the result that producers have been slaughtering their stock in excess of normal, in anticipation of the difficulties of procuring feeding-stuffs to maintain their stock over the winter. In addition, it has been a particularly good season this autumn for late grass which has led to the marketing of many beasts which would otherwise have been sold in the New Year. Home supplies will, therefore, almost certainly be less in the Spring of 19^4-0 than was anticipated. (b) Shipping delays have increased, so that the forecast of prospective arrivals of imported meat must be reduced. It would not be prudent to plan for the future on the assumption that these delays will be reduced. It is possible that they may be increased. (c) The French Food Commission have requested that 20,000 tons per month of frozen meat should be allocated to France for consumption by her front line troops. As regards (c), all negotiations for the purchase of meat pom South America for France as well as the United Kingdom are being onducted by the Ministry of Food so as to avoid competition for applies which would result in a rise in price in the country of origin. he French authorities notified the Ministry before the war that their equirements would be 20,000 tons per month. The request that I C,000 tons should be allocated to the French Army has been considered scently by the British side of the Inter-Allied Commission which ecommended that the request should be met. The French authorities Pe now asking that British tonnage amounting to at least 10*000 tons pace per month should be provided for the purpose of lifting their piuirements. This would almost certainly mean, if it were granted, a Auction of 10,000 tons of imported meat per month for civilian jQisunrption in the United Kingdom. As it seems probable that this loss U have to be accepted, allowance has been made for it in l e x II a. and b. The position with regard to building up a reserve of imported also requires explanation. In the first month of the quarter s t lancing I November, 1939, it has been possible to put aside the l^portionate amount of the reserve, thereby increasing
stocks of imported meat on 1st December, 1939, to some 70,000 tons. For the quarter commencing on 1st December, 1939, it is considered y desirable to put to reserve a further quantity of 80,000 tons, bringing the total reserves to 150,000 tons. This reserve would be eaual to one month's requirements of meat for all United Kingdom purposes and is regarded by the Trade Advisers of the Ministry as the smallest stock which would be safe to maintain as a working reserve. The reserve required to meet a catastrophe or a long abnormal delay in arrivals is on the hoof, i.e,, the farm livestock dispersed throughout the United Kingdom. v e r 6. The aggregate effect of the changes referred to in paragraph 3 and the necessity f o r the allocation of additional quantities to reserve in the current quarter (paragraph 5), has been to worsen the supply position. It will be seen from Annex II that the anticipated supplies during the three months December 1539 to February 1940 are estimated to provide 21 ozs. per head per week. For the following three months period the per head estimate is 19 ozs. per week, as compared with current consumption of k.0 ozs. (vide para. 2). Neither of these estimates contains any allowance for sinkings or other losses at sea or in ports. 7. In the case of meat, the ration will have to be expressed in terms of value, not weight. At present prices, 20 ozs. would be equivalent, on the average, to 1/od. But retail prices will, almost certainly, have to be revised before meat rationing can be introduced and the exact money equivalent of 20 ozs. cannot be foreseen at present. The Ministry of Pood hopes to be able to arrange for home-produced and imported meat to continue under rationing to be sold, as at present, at different price levels, both wholesale and retail, The supply position cannot be regarded as satisfactory eyond the middle of January. The facts set out in paragraphs * ** 6, coupled with the usual heavy demand on
supplies over the Christmas period,, make it necessary for action to be taken to safeguard future supplies. at A period of not less than four or five weeks is required to put rationing into force after the decision is taken. Registration of customers with butchers should, therefore, be proceeded with soon after Christmas. Registration of customers v/ith butchers is necessary in any case as part of the scheme of control of meat and livestock, which it has been decided to introduce early in the Hew Year to implement the pledge given to the farmers to buy their fatstock at guaranteed prices at an early date. 10. The small butcher is a particularly strong advocate for registration on the grounds that it will prevent the multiple butchers (as well a.s the Co-operative Societies) from continuing to attract his customers, as they are alleged to be doing at present, The Meat Trade Advisers of the Ministry are also unanimously in favour of registration of customers with retailers in advance of the livestock control scheme being put into operation. 11. It, therefore, appears to be necessary to invite the War Cabinet to take the following decisions as soon as possible:( a) that consumers should register with retailers for meat during the week beginning 1 s t January, 1940; (b) that the scheme for the control of livestock and home-produced meat should be brought into operation on the 15th January, 1940; and (c) that meat rationing should begin not later than 5 t h February, 1940. 12. It will not be necessary that any announcement as regards decision (a) and (c) should be made until after Christmas. Decision (b) has already been announced although the specific date, 1 5 t h January, has not yet been disclosed.
